info.game_comments:
1998 Teen Reunion Tournament preliminary game 2.
From the Wang Center for the Performing Arts in Boston, Massachusetts.

jeopardy_round: ON THE COVER OF ROLLING STONE

(1, 1).clue: Over its 2,340-mile course, this river forms the boundary or part of the boundary of 9 states

(2, 1).clue: He appeared alone on Rolling Stone's first cover November 9, 1967 & nude with Yoko a year later

(4, 1).clue: The endangered red variety of this animal once ranged from the Atlantic to Texas

(5, 1).clue: Introduced in 1982, it used the slogan "Just for the taste of it"

(6, 1).clue: Talleyrand resigned from this emperor's service in 1807 & began intriguing against him

(1, 2).clue: It's the largest body of fresh water lying entirely within the USA

(2, 2).clue: The stars of this sitcom, including Jason Alexander, hit the yellow brick road for the 1998 30th anniversary cover

(4, 2).clue: It's the dark endangered species seen here

(5, 2).clue: A syrup named for this "Mrs." was introduced in 1961; a pancake mix with her name on it came out in 1982

(6, 2).clue: Her husband, Franklin, was the godson of her father, Elliott

(1, 3).clue: Colorado's Mount Elbert in the Sawatch range is this mountain system's tallest peak

(2, 3).clue: He should get some "Satisfaction" knowing he's been on the cover more times than anyone else

(3, 3).clue: Last time a man walked on the moon

(4, 3).clue: In 1941 there were less than 2 dozen of this type of crane in North America

(5, 3).clue: Frank Epperson created it in 1923 when he pulled lemonade frozen onto a spoon out of a glass

(6, 3).clue: Drunk or sober, no one dared call this hatchet-wielding saloon smasher "Old Hatchet-Face"

(1, 4).clue: Francisco de Ortega is credited with discovering this strait leading into San Francisco Bay

(2, 4).clue: Anthony Kiedis went solo for a 1994 cover & appeared with this group on a '95 cover

(3, 4).clue: Ferdinand Marcos leaves the Philippines for the last time

(4, 4).clue: This endangered species of brown bear can grow to a height of 8 feet

(5, 4).clue: In 1993 Hershey introduced these white & milk chocolate treats as a companion to its Kisses

(6, 4).clue: Besides founding Pennsylvania, he found time to father more than 10 children

(1, 5).clue: This 113-mile sand bar along Texas' Gulf Coast is the state's largest island

(2, 5).clue: "Nothing Compares" to this singer seen on covers in 1990 & '91, & with even less hair in '92

(3, 5).clue: Chinese Nationalist government flees to Taiwan

(4, 5).clue: Use of pesticides like DDT have been a major cause of this type of falcon's decline

(5, 5).clue: In 1998 Frito-Lay introduced this line of olean-containing chips nationwide

(6, 5).clue: "The people made the Constitution and the people can unmake it", said this fourth chief justice

(1, 1).clue: This lord & poet known for his licentious behavior actually kept a pet bear at Cambridge

(2, 1).clue: Everybody knows the name of this long-running sitcom inspired by Boston's Bull & Finch Pub

(4, 1).clue: An item in a political platform, or a bad way off a pirate ship

(5, 1).clue: Jodie Bernstein, consumer protection head for the FTC, helped kill this animal symbol of Reynolds Tobacco

(6, 1).clue: "To be, or not to be:  for soon there will be no more me"

(1, 2).clue: This 1929 graduate acted at Cambridge long before hosting "Masterpiece Theatre"

(2, 2).clue: Its staff included doctors Donald Westphall, Mark Craig & Victor Ehrlich

(4, 2).clue: Get on the pirate ship, or a place for a company officer to sit

(5, 2).clue: In the '50s Walter Bernstein joined other Hollywood writers on this most unwanted list

(6, 2).clue: "Kiss me, Kate, though you're a meanie; now go cook some spaghettini!"

(1, 3).clue: This lord protector studied at Sidney Sussex College, & now his head is buried there

(2, 3).clue: Dylan McDermott heads up a small Boston law firm on this Emmy-winning drama

(4, 3).clue: Cutting trees down, or a word that describes the Frankenstein monster's walk

(5, 3).clue: Socialist Eduard Bernstein revised Karl Marx' ideas but stayed friends with this Marx pal & collaborator

(6, 3).clue: "My only love sprung from my only hate!  O!  Why can't I find a better date?"

(1, 4).clue: Though he was an Oxford graduate, he was selected to design the library at Trinity College in the 1670s

(2, 4).clue: Richard Ruccolo, Ryan Reynolds & Traylor Howard stick together through thick & thin crust on this sitcom
(2, 4).correct response: Two Guys, A Girl, And A Pizza Place

(4, 4).clue: A measure of firewood, or a string you can use to bind it

(5, 4).clue: In 1988 Leonard Bernstein's 70th birthday gala was held at this music center in the Berkshires

(6, 4).clue: "Out, darned Spot!  Out, I say!  I can't make this blood go away!"

(1, 5).clue: In the early 1500s this Dutch humanist taught Greek at Cambridge

(2, 5).clue: This Robert Urich series about a Boston detective was based on books by Robert B. Parker

(4, 5).clue: A long, squared-off piece of wood used in construction, or to smile ear-to-ear

(5, 5).clue: Henry Bernstein wrote a powerful play about this Biblical-era heroine who cut off Holofernes' head

(6, 5).clue: "I lov'd not wisely but too well; killed my wife, that's just not swell"

(0, 0).clue: Pioneered by pro hockey player Scott Olsen, it had 3 million U.S. participants in 1989 & has 30 million now
